docs.title: 👋 Welcome
docs.text:
This website is a practical introduction to Python.

It exists to help you:

  • understand what you are doing 🧠
  • see what the computer is doing 🖥️
  • gain confidence step by step 🚀

This is not a reference book. This is not theory for theory’s sake.

It is a learning path.

docs.title: ⚙️ How this course works
docs.text:
Each lesson follows the same logic:

  • short explanations ✍️
  • simple code 🧩
  • immediate output 👀

You read. You run the code. You observe the result.

That’s how learning happens.

docs.title: 🎯 What is expected from you
docs.text:
You are not expected to:

  • understand everything
  • remember everything
  • be perfect

You are expected to:

  • try ✅
  • run the code ▶️
  • observe the output 🔍

That’s it.

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 Who this course is for
docs.text:
This course is for:

  • beginners 🌱
  • engineers 🛠️
  • curious minds 🤔

No prior programming knowledge is required.

If you can read instructions, you can start.

docs.title: 🚦 Where to start
docs.text:
If this page makes sense to you, you are ready.

➡️ Go to 📘 Presentation — What is Python and understand the tool you are about to use.

docs.title: 🐍 What is Python
docs.text:
Python is a programming language.

It allows you to write instructions that the computer executes step by step.

Those instructions are:

  • explicit
  • predictable
  • executed in order

docs.title: 💡 Why Python exists
docs.text:
Programming is often presented as something complex.

Python was created to make it simpler.

When reading Python code, you should be able to say:

“I can guess what this does.”

That is not an accident. That is the design.

docs.title: 🔍 How Python is different from other languages
docs.text:
Many languages require:

  • heavy syntax
  • many symbols
  • strict rules early on

Python focuses on:

  • readability 📖
  • simplicity ✨
  • logic 🧠

You write less. You understand more.

docs.title: 🌐 Python and Network Engineers
docs.text:
If you work in networking, you already think logically.

You already:

  • follow procedures
  • apply configurations step by step
  • verify outputs
  • troubleshoot problems

Programming uses the same mindset.

The only difference:

  • instead of devices 🌍
  • you give instructions to the computer 💻

That’s why Python fits networking so well.

docs.title: 🧰 Why Python is useful in networking
docs.text:
With Python, a Network Engineer can:

  • automate repetitive tasks ⚡
  • validate configurations ✅
  • analyze command outputs 📊
  • reduce manual errors 🛑

Instead of repeating actions, you automate them.

docs.title: 🚀 What matters at the beginning
docs.text:
At the start, only two things matter:

  1. Writing code ✍️
  2. Reading output 👀

Everything else comes later.

docs.title: 👉 Next step
docs.text:
If this page makes sense to you, you are ready.

➡️ Go to Lesson 1 — Print & Output and write your first Python instruction 🐍

docs.title: 🧪 Code Examples — From Simple to Automation
docs.text: This section shows how Python code evolves step by step. Nothing fancy at the beginning. Just logic.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Very simple: see output
docs.text:
print("Hello, Network Engineer")

Goal: - understand that code runs - see immediate output

docs.title: 2️⃣ Variables + meaning
docs.text:
hostname = "EDGE-RBA-01"
status = "UP"

print(hostname, "status is", status)

Goal: - store information - read code like a sentence

docs.title: 3️⃣ Conditions (decisions)
docs.text:
status = "down"

if status.lower() == "up":
    print("Interface is UP")
else:
    print("Interface is DOWN")

Goal: - make decisions - understand execution paths

docs.title: 4️⃣ Loop over multiple elements
docs.text:
interfaces = ["Gi0/0", "Gi0/1", "Gi0/2"]

for iface in interfaces:
    print("Checking", iface)

Goal: - stop repeating yourself - apply the same logic everywhere

docs.title: 5️⃣ Structured data (network-style)
docs.text:
interfaces = [
    {"name": "Gi0/0", "status": "up"},
    {"name": "Gi0/1", "status": "down"},
]

for iface in interfaces:
    if iface["status"] != "up":
        print("ALERT:", iface["name"])

Goal: - treat the network as data - prepare for automation

docs.title: 6️⃣ Functions (reusable logic)
docs.text:
def is_down(iface):
    return iface["status"] != "up"

for iface in interfaces:
    if is_down(iface):
        print("ALERT:", iface["name"])

Goal: - reuse logic - make code readable and testable

docs.title: 7️⃣ Real automation mindset
docs.text:
devices = [
    {"hostname": "EDGE-RBA-01", "status": "up"},
    {"hostname": "EDGE-CAS-01", "status": "down"},
]

alerts = []

for d in devices:
    if d["status"] != "up":
        alerts.append(d["hostname"])

print("Total alerts:", len(alerts))
for host in alerts:
    print("ALERT |", host)

Goal: - input → process → output - clean, trustworthy automation

docs.title: Final thought
docs.text:
Automation is not about writing complex code.

It’s about: - starting simple - understanding each step - stacking small pieces of logic

That’s how Python becomes useful for networking.

docs.title: ⚙️ Before you start
docs.text:
Before writing any Python code, make sure Python is installed on your machine.

  • Download Python from the official website: https://www.python.org/downloads/
  • Run every command yourself
  • Take your time

Learning Python is not about speed. Discipline is more important than understanding everything immediately.

docs.title: 🎯 What you are about to do
docs.text:
In Lesson 1, you will:

  • write your first Python code
  • see immediate results
  • understand what the computer is doing

You are not expected to:

  • understand everything
  • remember everything
  • be perfect

You are expected to:

  • try
  • run the code
  • observe the output

That’s it.

docs.title: 🧠 Programming is not magic
docs.text:
Programming is often presented as something complex.

In reality, it is very simple:

you write instructions the computer follows them

The computer does not:

  • think
  • guess
  • understand intentions

It only follows exact instructions.

This is good news.

docs.title: 🖨️ What is print()
docs.text:
print() is a function.

A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific action.

The role of print() is to: - display information for humans - show what the program is doing

The computer executes code silently. print() is how you see what happens.

docs.title: ▶️ Your first Python instruction
docs.text:
Run this code:

print("Hello, Python")

What happens:

  • Python reads the instruction
  • Python executes it
  • Python displays the output

Instruction → execution → output

docs.title: 🧰 Built-in functions in Python
docs.text:
Python comes with built-in functions.

They are:

  • already created
  • already available
  • ready to use

Examples:

  • print()
  • len()
  • type()
  • input()

You did not create print(). Python provides it by default.

docs.title: 🛠️ Common uses of print()
docs.text:
You use print() to:

  • display results
  • debug code
  • confirm actions
  • explain what a script is doing
  • make automation readable

Automation without output is dangerous.

docs.title: Printing text
docs.text: print("Network automation starts here")

docs.title: Printing numbers
docs.text: print(42)

docs.title: Printing multiple values
docs.text: print("Interface", "eth0", "is", "UP")

docs.title: Separator (sep)
docs.text:
print("eth0", "eth1", "eth2", sep=" | ")

Output: 

eth0 | eth1 | eth2

docs.title: Line ending (end)
docs.text:
print("Checking interface...", end=" ")
print("DONE")

Output: 

Checking interface... DONE

docs.title: 🌐 Why output matters
docs.text:
In networking, you always:

  • run a command
  • read the output
  • trust the result

Programming works the same way.

Clean output means:

  • easier debugging
  • safer automation
  • scripts others can trust

docs.title: 🚀 What matters most in this lesson
docs.text:
At the beginning, only two things matter:

  • writing code
  • reading output

Everything else comes later.

Clean output is how humans trust automation. That is why this course starts with print().

docs.title: ✅ You are done
docs.text:
If you:

  • installed Python
  • ran the examples
  • observed the output

You completed this lesson.

Go to Lesson 2 — Variables & Values and continue.

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text:
In this lesson, you will: - understand what a variable is - learn the 3 core types you will use all the time (numbers, strings, booleans) - learn the biggest beginner traps (and how to avoid them) - do a mini network-style exercise

You are expected to: - run every code block - change values and observe output - never guess: print it

docs.title: What is a variable (simple definition)
docs.text:
A variable is a label that points to a value.

site = "Rabat"
print(site)

Think of it like a sticky note on a box.

docs.title: Core types you will use everywhere
Numbers (int / float)
docs.text:
mtu = 1500
delay_ms = 12.5
print(mtu, delay_ms)

docs.title: Strings (text)
docs.text:
hostname = "EDGE-RBA-01"
print(hostname)

docs.title: Booleans (True / False)
docs.text:
is_up = True
is_shutdown = False
print(is_up, is_shutdown)

docs.title: Trap 1 — Quotes change everything
docs.text:
These are NOT the same:

print(22)      # number
print("22")    # text

Why it matters in networking: - numbers are used for math (counters, timers, VLAN IDs) - strings are used for labels and parsing (hostnames, interface names)

docs.title: Trap 2 — = is assignment, == is comparison
docs.text:
x = 10      # assign
print(x == 10)  # compare (True)

docs.title: Trap 3 — Python is case-sensitive
docs.text:
Status = "UP"
# print(status)  # NameError (different name)
print(Status)

docs.title: Reassigning values (normal and useful)
docs.text:
Variables can change over time:

status = "DOWN"
print("Before:", status)

status = "UP"
print("After:", status)

This is how you model “state” (like interface status).

docs.title: Reading variables mentally
docs.text:
Train this habit:

  • read from right to left on assignment
  • say it out loud in your head

Example: 

vlan = 100
iface = "GigabitEthernet0/0"
Mental reading: - “vlan equals 100” - “iface equals GigabitEthernet0/0”

docs.title: Network mini-lab: build a clean status line
docs.text:
Run this:

hostname = "EDGE-RBA-01"
iface = "GigabitEthernet0/0"
is_up = True

print("Host:", hostname)
print("Interface:", iface)
print("Up:", is_up)

Now change: - hostname - iface - is_up

Observe how your output changes.

docs.title: Exercise (do it now)
docs.text:
Goal: Print this exact output (with your own values):

EDGE-RBA-01 | GigabitEthernet0/0 | UP

Rules: - create 3 variables: hostname, iface, status - use ONE print() call - use sep=" | "

Starter:

hostname = "EDGE-RBA-01"
iface = "GigabitEthernet0/0"
status = "UP"

# your print here

Expected solution pattern: 

print(hostname, iface, status, sep=" | ")

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - use math operators (useful for counters, timers, sizing) - compare values (the core of “is this OK?”) - use boolean logic (and / or / not) - read conditions like English (no panic)

docs.title: Arithmetic operators (quick + useful)
docs.text:
packets_in = 1200
packets_out = 950
total = packets_in + packets_out
print("Total packets:", total)

Common operators: - + add - - subtract - * multiply - / divide (float) - // floor divide (int) - % modulo (remainder)

docs.title: Network example: check packet loss percent
docs.text:
sent = 1000
received = 970
loss = sent - received
loss_pct = (loss / sent) * 100
print("Loss %:", loss_pct)

docs.title: Comparison operators (the “truth” operators)
docs.text:
They return True or False.

mtu = 1500
print(mtu == 1500)  # True
print(mtu != 1500)  # False
print(mtu > 1400)   # True

Common comparisons: - == equal - != not equal - > greater - < less - >= greater or equal - <= less or equal

docs.title: and (both must be True)
docs.text:
bgp_up = True
ping_ok = True
print(bgp_up and ping_ok)  # True

docs.title: or (at least one True)
docs.text:
primary_ok = False
backup_ok = True
print(primary_ok or backup_ok)  # True

docs.title: not (flip)
docs.text:
is_shutdown = False
print(not is_shutdown)  # True

docs.title: The big pitfall: mixing strings and numbers
docs.text:
vlan = "100"
# print(vlan + 1)  # TypeError
print(int(vlan) + 1)     # 101

If you parse text from device output, you often need conversions.

docs.title: Read conditions like English
docs.text:
Example:

cpu = 78
mem = 65

if cpu > 80 or mem > 80:
    print("Alert")

Read it as:

“If CPU is above 80 OR memory is above 80, print Alert.”

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
You are given:

latency_ms = 42
loss_pct = 1.8

Goal: print OK only if: - latency is <= 50 - and loss is < 2

Starter:

latency_ms = 42
loss_pct = 1.8

# your if here

Expected output (with given values): 

OK

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - make decisions with if - learn how Python chooses a branch - avoid the 3 classic mistakes - write a network-style decision (UP/DOWN)

docs.title: The simplest decision
docs.text:
temperature = 31

if temperature > 30:
    print("Hot")

If the condition is True, the block runs.

docs.title: Condition flow (only ONE branch runs)
docs.text:
score = 75

if score >= 90:
    print("A")
elif score >= 70:
    print("B")
else:
    print("C")

Python checks from top to bottom and stops at the first match.

docs.title: Mistake 1 — forgetting indentation
docs.text: Indentation is not style in Python. It is logic.

docs.title: Mistake 2 — using = instead of ==
docs.text:
x = 5
if x == 5:
    print("OK")

docs.title: Mistake 3 — comparing text with wrong case
docs.text:
status = "up"
print(status == "UP")  # False
print(status.upper() == "UP")  # True

docs.title: Network example: interpret interface status
docs.text:
iface = "GigabitEthernet0/0"
status = "up"

if status.lower() == "up":
    print(iface, "is UP")
else:
    print(iface, "is DOWN")

docs.title: Network example: multi-level decision
docs.text:
cpu = 83
if cpu >= 90:
    print("CRITICAL")
elif cpu >= 80:
    print("WARNING")
else:
    print("OK")

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
Goal: print the correct message for this device.

Rules: - if site is "Rabat" and link_up is True → print "Rabat link OK" - else → print "Check link"

Starter:

site = "Rabat"
link_up = True

# your if here

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - repeat actions with loops (automation mindset) - loop over lists of interfaces/devices - count things safely - understand when loops stop

docs.title: for loop (repeat for each item)
docs.text:
interfaces = ["eth0", "eth1", "eth2"]

for iface in interfaces:
    print("Checking", iface)

docs.title: Counting with conditions
docs.text:
interfaces = [
    {"name": "eth0", "up": True},
    {"name": "eth1", "up": False},
    {"name": "eth2", "up": True},
]

down = 0
for iface in interfaces:
    if not iface["up"]:
        down += 1

print("Down interfaces:", down)

docs.title: The biggest pitfall: infinite while loops
docs.text:
A while loop repeats while the condition is True.

x = 0
while x < 3:
    print("x =", x)
    x += 1

If you forget x += 1, it can run forever.

docs.title: Network example: retry logic (simple)
docs.text:
attempts = 0
max_attempts = 3
ping_ok = False

while attempts < max_attempts and not ping_ok:
    attempts += 1
    print("Attempt", attempts, "- ping...")

    # pretend we succeed on the 3rd try
    if attempts == 3:
        ping_ok = True

print("Ping OK:", ping_ok)

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
You have a list of devices. Print only the ones in France.

devices = [
    {"name": "RBA-EDGE-01", "country": "MA"},
    {"name": "PAR-EDGE-01", "country": "FR"},
    {"name": "LYO-EDGE-02", "country": "FR"},
]

Expected output: 

PAR-EDGE-01
LYO-EDGE-02

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - understand lists (ordered data) - understand dictionaries (key/value data) - access and update values safely - see why dictionaries are everywhere in networking

docs.title: Lists: ordered data
docs.text:
A list is an ordered collection.

ports = [22, 80, 443]
print(ports[0])  # 22

Pitfall: - index starts at 0 (not 1)

docs.title: Dictionaries: key/value logic
docs.text:
A dictionary maps a key to a value.

iface = {"name": "eth0", "status": "UP", "mtu": 1500}
print(iface["status"])

Pitfall: - wrong key → KeyError

Safer access: 

print(iface.get("speed", "UNKNOWN"))

docs.title: Update values
docs.text:
iface["status"] = "DOWN"
print(iface)

docs.title: Why dictionaries are everywhere in networking
docs.text:
Networking data is naturally key/value: - interface name → status - device → IP - tunnel → metrics - VLAN → subnet

Example (very real automation shape):

device = {
    "hostname": "EDGE-RBA-01",
    "mgmt_ip": "10.10.10.10",
    "site": "Rabat",
    "roles": ["sdwan", "wan-edge"],
}
print(device["hostname"], device["mgmt_ip"])

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
You have interface data:

iface = {"name": "GigabitEthernet0/0", "status": "down"}

Goal: - print GigabitEthernet0/0 is DOWN (uppercase status) - without changing the original dictionary

Hint: - use .upper() on the value

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - understand what error messages mean - recognize the most common beginner errors - debug calmly (like a network engineer) - learn a simple debugging process

docs.title: Errors are not failures
docs.text:
Errors are feedback.

They tell you: - what went wrong - where it went wrong - what Python expected

Your job is not to panic. Your job is to read.

docs.title: 1) SyntaxError (Python cannot parse the code)
docs.text:
Example: 

print("hello"

docs.title: 2) IndentationError (blocks not aligned)
docs.text:
Example: 

if True:
print("x")

docs.title: 3) NameError (variable not defined)
docs.text:
Example: 

print(hostname)  # hostname not created yet

docs.title: 4) TypeError (wrong type for an operation)
docs.text:
Example: 

print("10" + 1)

docs.title: 5) KeyError (dictionary key missing)
docs.text:
Example: 

d = {"a": 1}
print(d["b"])

docs.title: Read stack traces calmly
docs.text:
A stack trace usually shows: - file - line number - error type - message

Rule: - start from the bottom line (the error) - then go to the line number in your code

docs.title: Debugging mindset (network-style)
docs.text:
In networking, you do: - observe - isolate - test - validate

In Python, do the same.

docs.title: A simple debugging process
docs.text:
When code fails:

  1. Read the error type (SyntaxError? NameError?)
  2. Go to the exact line
  3. Print variables around it
  4. Change one thing
  5. Run again

docs.title: Debug tool #1: print
docs.text:
Yes, print is a debugging tool.

status = "UP"
print("DEBUG status =", status)

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
This code is broken. Fix it.

iface = {"name": "eth0", "up": "True"}
if iface["up"] == True:
    print(iface["name"], "is UP")

Hints: - "True" is text, not boolean - make the condition correct

docs.title: Why functions exist
docs.text: Functions help you: - avoid repetition - reuse logic safely - make code readable - build automation that scales

docs.title: A function is a tool
docs.text: You give it input. It returns output.

docs.title: The simplest function
docs.text:
def say_hello():
    print("Hello")

Call it: 

say_hello()

docs.title: Inputs and outputs
docs.text:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(2, 3)
print(result)

Key idea: - return gives a value back to the caller - print only displays text

docs.title: Network example: normalize interface status
docs.text:
def normalize_status(status):
    return status.strip().lower()

print(normalize_status(" UP "))

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
Write a function is_up(status) that returns True if status is "up" (any case).

Starter: 

def is_up(status):
    # your code
    pass

docs.title: What you are about to do
docs.text: In this lesson, you will: - write functions with def - use parameters - return values - call functions like building blocks

docs.title: Your first useful function
docs.text:
def greet(name):
    print("Hello", name)

greet("Badr")

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
Parameters are inputs.

def tag(site, device):
    return site + "-" + device

print(tag("RBA", "EDGE01"))

docs.title: Return values
docs.text:
Return is the “output” of the function.

def double(x):
    return x * 2

print(double(10))

docs.title: Network example: build a status line
docs.text:
def status_line(hostname, iface, status):
    return hostname + " | " + iface + " | " + status.upper()

print(status_line("EDGE-RBA-01", "Gi0/0", "up"))

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
Write a function is_vlan_valid(vlan) that returns True if vlan is between 1 and 4094.

Starter: 

def is_vlan_valid(vlan):
    # your code
    pass

docs.title: Returning vs printing
docs.text:
• print() shows output to humans
  • return gives output to code

Good automation: - returns data - prints only clean summaries

docs.title: Bad pattern (hard to reuse)
docs.text:
def add(a, b):
    print(a + b)

docs.title: Good pattern (reusable)
docs.text:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

print(add(2, 3))

docs.title: Network example: validation function
docs.text:
def is_mtu_ok(mtu):
    return mtu == 1500

mtu = 1500
if is_mtu_ok(mtu):
    print("MTU OK")
else:
    print("MTU WRONG")

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
Write a function format_alert(host, message) that returns:

ALERT | <host> | <message>

Then print it.

docs.title: Passing data to functions
docs.text: Automation often uses lists of devices and dicts of attributes.

docs.title: Example: count down interfaces
docs.text:
def count_down(interfaces):
    down = 0
    for iface in interfaces:
        if iface["status"].lower() != "up":
            down += 1
    return down

interfaces = [
    {"name": "eth0", "status": "UP"},
    {"name": "eth1", "status": "down"},
]

print(count_down(interfaces))

docs.title: Return structured results
docs.text:
def summarize_device(device):
    return {
        "hostname": device["hostname"],
        "site": device["site"],
        "ok": device["status"].lower() == "up",
    }

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text: Given a list of devices, return a list of hostnames that are down.

docs.title: Lesson 12 — Network Data as Python Data
Network = data
docs.text: Automation becomes easy when you treat networks as data: - interfaces → dictionaries - devices → dictionaries - inventory → list of dictionaries - configs → text

docs.title: Interfaces as dictionaries
docs.text:
iface = {"name": "Gi0/0", "admin": "up", "oper": "down", "mtu": 1500}
print(iface["name"], iface["oper"])

docs.title: Device lists
docs.text:
devices = [
    {"hostname": "EDGE-RBA-01", "mgmt_ip": "10.0.0.1"},
    {"hostname": "EDGE-CAS-01", "mgmt_ip": "10.0.0.2"},
]

docs.title: Config as text
docs.text:
config = "interface Gi0/0
 description WAN
 ip address 10.0.0.1 255.255.255.0
"
print(config)

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
Create a dictionary for a device with: - hostname - mgmt_ip - site - role

Then print one clean summary line.

docs.title: Lesson 12 — Python for Networking: Libraries & the Big Picture
What you are about to do
docs.text: In this part, you will learn why Python matters for networking: - how Python talks to devices (SSH, APIs) - which libraries are common in network automation - how “network = data” becomes real work (inventory, reports, config pushes) - why you should always start from a real need and build step by step

docs.title: Python is interpreted (why that’s good)
docs.text:
Python is an interpreted language: - you write code - the Python interpreter runs it immediately

Why it helps: - fast feedback (run → see output → adjust) - easy debugging - perfect for iterative automation

docs.title: The mindset: start from a need
docs.text:
The best scripts are not “cool scripts”. They are scripts that solve a real pain.

Example needs: - “I need to check BGP status on 50 routers every morning.” - “I need to push a safe config snippet on 80 sites.” - “I need a report in Excel for management.”

Rule:

Need → small steps → reliable output → scale

docs.title: Common networking libraries (the ones you’ll see in real jobs)
SSH / CLI automation
docs.text:
• Netmiko: simple SSH automation to network devices (popular, practical)
  • Scrapli: modern alternative (fast, clean)
  • Paramiko: low-level SSH building block (more manual)

docs.title: Multi-vendor configuration / state
docs.text: • NAPALM: vendor abstraction (get facts, interfaces, config, etc.)

docs.title: Network protocols
docs.text:
• ncclient: NETCONF (structured configs, automation workflows)
  • pygnmi: gNMI (telemetry / config on supported platforms)

docs.title: APIs
docs.text: • requests: talk to REST APIs (controllers, SD-WAN managers, cloud)

docs.title: Input / Output libraries (inventory + reports)
docs.text:
Automation is not just connecting. It is also reading/writing data.

Common ones: - csv (built-in): read/write CSV device inventories - json (built-in): structured data and APIs - pathlib (built-in): safe file paths - openpyxl (Excel): read/write .xlsx - pandas (dataframes): reports + Excel + CSV fast - yaml (PyYAML): config files and inventories (common in automation)

docs.title: Your first “real” automation architecture
docs.text:
A good network script usually looks like this:

  1. Input: load devices from CSV/Excel/YAML
  2. Connect: SSH/API
  3. Collect: run commands / get facts
  4. Decide: logic checks (OK/ALERT)
  5. Output: clean summary + save report

Keep it simple. Then scale.

docs.title: Mini exercise (no device required)
docs.text:
Make a tiny inventory and print it cleanly:

devices = [
    {"hostname": "EDGE-RBA-01", "ip": "10.0.0.1", "site": "Rabat"},
    {"hostname": "EDGE-CAS-01", "ip": "10.0.0.2", "site": "Casablanca"},
]

for d in devices:
    print(d["hostname"], d["ip"], d["site"], sep=" | ")

Expected output: 

EDGE-RBA-01 | 10.0.0.1 | Rabat
EDGE-CAS-01 | 10.0.0.2 | Casablanca

docs.title: Lesson 13 — Inventory & I/O: TXT / CSV / Excel
Why I/O matters
docs.text:
Network automation always starts with inventory: - device list - credentials (never hardcode in files) - platform / vendor - site / role

You also need outputs: - clean terminal output - CSV/Excel report - logs for troubleshooting

docs.title: Option 1: TXT inventory (simple)
docs.text:
devices.txt example (one IP per line): 

10.0.0.1
10.0.0.2
10.0.0.3

Read it:

with open("devices.txt", "r") as f:
    devices = [line.strip() for line in f if line.strip()]

print(devices)

Pitfall: - empty lines - spaces at the end → use .strip()

docs.title: Option 2: CSV inventory (best simple standard)
docs.text:
devices.csv example: 

hostname,ip,platform,site
EDGE-RBA-01,10.0.0.1,cisco_ios,Rabat
EDGE-CAS-01,10.0.0.2,cisco_ios,Casablanca

Read it (built-in csv):

import csv

devices = []
with open("devices.csv", newline="") as f:
    reader = csv.DictReader(f)
    for row in reader:
        devices.append(row)

print(devices[0])

Pitfalls: - column names must match exactly - everything is read as string

docs.title: Option 3: Excel inventory (when business wants .xlsx)
docs.text:
Use openpyxl or pandas.

Example with pandas (fast):

import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_excel("devices.xlsx")
print(df.head())

Write a report:

df.to_excel("report.xlsx", index=False)

Pitfalls: - Excel file locked/open in another program - mixed types in columns

    {"name": "Gi0/0", "status": "up"},
    {"name": "Gi0/1", "status": "down"},
    {"name": "Gi0/2", "status": "down"},

docs.title: Lesson 14 — Connect to a Device & Retrieve Common Information
What you are about to do
docs.text: You will learn: - how a script connects to a device using a library (example: Netmiko) - how to run common show commands - how to store results cleanly

docs.title: Library example: Netmiko (SSH to network devices)
docs.text:
Install: 

pip install netmiko

Basic pattern: - define device parameters - connect - run commands - disconnect

docs.title: Example: collect hostname, version, interfaces (Cisco IOS-like)
docs.text:
from netmiko import ConnectHandler

device = {
    "device_type": "cisco_ios",
    "host": "10.0.0.1",
    "username": "admin",
    "password": "YOUR_PASSWORD",
}

conn = ConnectHandler(**device)

hostname = conn.send_command("show run | i hostname")
version = conn.send_command("show version | i Version")
interfaces = conn.send_command("show ip interface brief")

conn.disconnect()

print(hostname)
print(version)
print(interfaces)

Pitfalls: - wrong device_type - SSH blocked / ACL - credentials wrong - command differs by platform

docs.title: Make output readable (important)
docs.text:
Instead of printing huge walls, print a summary:

print("=== SUMMARY ===")
print(hostname.strip())
print(version.strip())
print("Interfaces lines:", len(interfaces.splitlines()))

docs.text:
Take a long text output (multi-line string) and: - count lines - check if a keyword exists (like "down")

Starter:

output = \"\"\"Gi0/0 up
Gi0/1 down
Gi0/2 up
\"\"\"

docs.title: One function = one task
docs.text: Good automation uses small functions: - easy to test - easy to reuse - easy to trust

docs.title: Example: normalize text
docs.text:
def norm(text):
    return text.strip().lower()

docs.title: Example: one function for one check
docs.text:
def is_interface_up(iface):
    return iface["status"].lower() == "up"

iface = {"name": "Gi0/0", "status": "up"}
print(is_interface_up(iface))

docs.title: Clean separation of concerns
docs.text:
• parsing: extract data
  • logic: decide
  • output: display

docs.title: Why concurrency matters
docs.text:
If you have: - 5 devices → sequential is fine - 50 devices → sequential is slow - 500 devices → sequential is pain

Python can run tasks in parallel using concurrent.futures.

docs.title: The safe mental model
docs.text: One function does one device. Then we run that function across a list of devices.

docs.title: Example: collect show clock from many devices (Netmiko + threads)
docs.text:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed
from netmiko import ConnectHandler

def collect_clock(device):
    conn = ConnectHandler(**device)
    out = conn.send_command("show clock")
    conn.disconnect()
    return device["host"], out.strip()

devices = [
    {"device_type": "cisco_ios", "host": "10.0.0.1", "username": "admin", "password": "PWD"},
    {"device_type": "cisco_ios", "host": "10.0.0.2", "username": "admin", "password": "PWD"},
]

results = []
with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=10) as ex:
    futures = [ex.submit(collect_clock, d) for d in devices]
    for f in as_completed(futures):
        results.append(f.result())

for host, clock in results:
    print(host, "=>", clock)

Pitfalls: - too many threads can overload your jump host or devices - handle exceptions (timeouts/auth failures)

docs.text:
line = "Gi0/1 is down"
parts = line.split()
iface = parts[0]
status = parts[-1]
print(iface, status)

docs.text:
Text is messy: - extra spaces - different cases - different formats

Normalize first:

docs.title: Lesson 16 — Push Config on Multiple Devices (Safely) ✅
The goal
docs.text: You want to: - push a small config snippet - validate with checks - do it across multiple devices - keep output clean and trustworthy

docs.title: The rule: never “blind push”
docs.text: Always do: 1. pre-check 2. push 3. post-check 4. report

docs.title: Example: push a description on an interface (Netmiko)
docs.text:
from netmiko import ConnectHandler

device = {
    "device_type": "cisco_ios",
    "host": "10.0.0.1",
    "username": "admin",
    "password": "PWD",
}

commands = [
    "interface GigabitEthernet0/0",
    "description Managed by Python",
]

conn = ConnectHandler(**device)

pre = conn.send_command("show run interface GigabitEthernet0/0 | i description")
out = conn.send_config_set(commands)
post = conn.send_command("show run interface GigabitEthernet0/0 | i description")

conn.save_config()  # for platforms that support it (IOS: write mem / etc. netmiko handles per platform sometimes)
conn.disconnect()

print("PRE:", pre.strip())
print("POST:", post.strip())

Pitfalls: - wrong interface name - command syntax differs per platform - saving config differs across platforms

docs.title: Multi-device safe push (with concurrency + result report)
docs.text:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed
from netmiko import ConnectHandler

COMMANDS = [
    "interface GigabitEthernet0/0",
    "description Managed by Python",
]

def push_and_check(device):
    host = device["host"]
    conn = ConnectHandler(**device)

    pre = conn.send_command("show run interface GigabitEthernet0/0 | i description")
    conn.send_config_set(COMMANDS)
    post = conn.send_command("show run interface GigabitEthernet0/0 | i description")

    conn.disconnect()

    ok = "Managed by Python" in post
    return {
        "host": host,
        "pre": pre.strip(),
        "post": post.strip(),
        "ok": ok,
    }

devices = [
    {"device_type": "cisco_ios", "host": "10.0.0.1", "username": "admin", "password": "PWD"},
    {"device_type": "cisco_ios", "host": "10.0.0.2", "username": "admin", "password": "PWD"},
]

results = []
with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=10) as ex:
    futures = [ex.submit(push_and_check, d) for d in devices]
    for f in as_completed(futures):
        results.append(f.result())

print("=== REPORT ===")
for r in results:
    status = "OK" if r["ok"] else "FAIL"
    print(r["host"], "|", status, "|", r["post"])

docs.title: Why people need Python (the real value)
docs.text:
With Python you can: - do the same work on 100 devices in minutes - reduce human errors - produce consistent reports - build repeatable, testable procedures

That’s why Python fits networking so well.

docs.title: Lesson 17 — Think Like an Automation Engineer
Lesson 17 — How to Think Like an Automation Engineer
Structure first
docs.text: Before writing code: - define inputs - define outputs - define success conditions

docs.title: Logic before tools
docs.text: Tools change. Logic stays.

docs.title: Reliability over speed
docs.text: Fast scripts that lie are dangerous. Slow scripts that are correct are valuable.

docs.title: What to learn after the basics
docs.text: Next topics that unlock real automation: - working with files (read/write) - using libraries (Netmiko, NAPALM) - structured data (JSON, YAML) - logging and error handling

docs.title: When to use libraries
docs.text: Use libraries when: - you repeat the same patterns - you need SSH/API - you want reliability

docs.title: How to grow safely
docs.text:
• build small projects
  • test often
  • keep output clean
  • document your scripts
